Arimyth:

The point of considering the audience he has access to with his youtube project is to weigh the time and effort as well as the royalty aspect of his endeavor relative to the payout

It‚Äôs interesting. It depends on who‚Äôs creating the ‚Äòmusic video‚Äô ‚Äì i.e. whether the Auxy cover artist is providing the channel with a readymade video containing the Auxy cover, or they‚Äôre providing the channel owner with just the music and the channel owner is adding imagery to it.

The one who adds imagery/video is the one who should be getting the synch licensing.

If the Auxy artist is providing the video file, the only royalties the channel owner would need to worry about are those owed to the Auxy cover artist, as they‚Äôre merely reposting a new original synched recording. However, we‚Äôd assume that the Auxy cover artist would waive those royalties due from the channel owner.

(Of course, one option would be for the Auxy cover artist to register their creation with the Content ID system, so that any revenue generated on YT from that music video would be redirected back to themselves.)

The Auxy cover artist would be the ones who need to worry about royalties owed to the original publisher.
If they‚Äôre also creating the video file (with still/moving imagery) they‚Äôd need to take care of the synch licensing too.

 
Although, as mentioned in the CDBaby FAQ article, many don‚Äôt which is why the Content ID system and automated claims on monetisation are typically used to handle things on YT now.

Note: Content ID is based on recordings, not published words and music, per se.
but, if a cover is very close to the original recording, it‚Äôs possible that it could be incorrectly identified as that original recording and an automated claim issued.

It‚Äôs complex and messy, for sure.

 

it did strike me that the latter is what he was considering rather than a purely reposting channel

Those distributing commercially (via distribution services like Amuse for example) would not be the best candidates to try to duck out of royalties for.

For sure, but as mentioned, even publicly posting on SC or YT (and possibly even here, as it‚Äôs a public forum) qualifies as a commercial release, as the Auxy artist is potentially able to benefit commercially, either directly from monetisation, or indirectly, by advertising the (Auxy) artist.

Whether or not the (Auxy) cover is likely to actually generate revenue has no bearing on its classification as a commercial release.

which might not justify the royalties he‚Äôd have to pay on a per track basis. However, that‚Äôs for NightOwl to decide.

It would be for the Auxy artist themselves to pay the royalties, not @NightOwl as the reposting channel owner.
(Unless NightOwl is considering a label/releasing agent/distributor arrangement, which is unlikely.)

 
All that said, the CDBaby/DIY Musician post linked earlier does a fairly good job of explaining what would actually happen for cover versions released without royalties ‚Äì i.e. YT‚Äôs Content ID algo might identify it, and the publisher would automatically take any monetisation.
(Check out the section on ‚ÄòSynch licensing‚Äô.)

 
One thing I‚Äôm not clear about is what happens when YT‚Äôs Content ID algo identifies a cover track that does have a synch license and royalties paid up.
In those situations, the publisher wouldn‚Äôt have the right to take the monetisation. I would assume the cover artist would need to counter-claim and show that they‚Äôve got those things sorted.
